item.title: Wall Street set to rise in early trade
item.description: US equity index futures were higher, indicating a positive open for Wall Street, as investors were soothed by stronger global stocks, however a slew of mixed earnings results could spark volatility.

item.title: ExxonMobil quarterly profits fall 66%
item.description: ExxonMobil, the largest US oil company, said its second quarter profits fell by 66 per cent as the global downturn sapped demand for fuel and dragged down energy prices

item.title: New US jobless claims rise to 584,000
item.description: The number of US workers claiming unemployment benefits rose last week, but remain below levels seen during the worst of the recession, raising optimism that the labour market could slowly be starting to heal.

item.title: US regulator criticises Obama bank plan
item.description: The Obama administration’s plan to give US states more power to protect consumers from unfair banking practices would make it more difficult and costly for large lenders to operate across the country, a financial regulator has warned

item.title: Sony profits beat expectations
item.description: Sony announced a smaller than expected first quarter net loss of Y37.1bn because of stockmarket gains in its financial subsidiary and cost cuts that reduced losses in its core electronics business

item.title: Microsoft and Yahoo seal deal
item.description: Yahoo ran into a fresh wave of doubts in the financial and technology worlds as it bowed out of the race to compete with Google

item.title: NYSE Euronext swings to loss
item.description: The transatlantic exchange swung into a second quarter loss after absorbing a whopping $355m one-time charge, but seen ‘accretive’ by year-end

item.title: UK regulator summons oil market players
item.description: The UK regulator has called a special meeting of oil market participants to review regulation of the commodity market following last year’s record rise in crude prices

item.title: Trustee sues Madoff’s wife for $45m
item.description: Ruth Madoff was sued for $44.8m on Wednesday and accused of living a “life of splendour” by the trustee seeking to recover money for the victims of her husband, the disgraced former broker Bernard Madoff

item.title: Short View: Shanghai surprise
item.description: A sell-off in Chinese shares may be more than a technical correction, writes John Authers
